column1: #Text=Essentially you would want to revoke Massachusetts ' ability to have gay marriage ?
#Text=So that would be anti-States rights to a degree ?
#Text=But my point is that when I said I 'm for states rights , I 'm also for recognizing the fact that there are some issues in which the nation has an interest .
#Text=Why do you think gay marriage is one of those issues ?
#Text=I think that 's a center piece , the most important institution in our country , is the marriage .
#Text=Its most important role is as the protector of children .
#Text=I think central to the American family , which is the most central institution in the country , is the marriage between a man and a wife .
#Text=I think we need to elevate that traditional marriage .
#Text=I think that it devalues it by rendering it less than what it was , by making it something that is not a function of the Judeo-Christian tradition , which most of our laws are built on .
#Text=Although we are not a Christian nation --
#Text=As you start to devalue the traditional marriage , people would ask why ca n't it simply be a contract between a number of people ?
#Text=What 's special about a man and a wife ?
#Text=I think there is something special about a man and a wife , and in a way the traditional marriage is different than many institutions .
#Text=It is an institution that has a religious element to it .
#Text=It 's a part of a our Judeo-Christian tradition .
#Text=The argument against that is should government be involved in it at all then .
#Text=But it is recognized , and protected , by government .
#Text=So that makes it an unusual institution .
#Text=What about when two Muslims marry , then ?
#Text=Well , I 'm saying that was the basis of the traditional marriage in our society that made it an important institution in this society .
#Text=That does n't mean it is restricted of one religious group , but that it has been a function of Judeo-Christian religion and has become thereby a part of our laws .
#Text=Since it exists in all societies , just because it is practiced by a Judeo-Christian society does that make it a Judeo-Christian institution or a human institution ?
#Text=Well , I think you can argue that , but --

#Text=No , I said you could argue that , but in this society it has been a function of the Judeo-Christian religion , although it is supported similarly by other religions , and by diverse numbers of ethnic groups .
#Text=On the other hand , that 's not a reason to not support it , to not elevate it , and not to honor it .
